nodes.text: Large increases in Chinese manufacturing exports (the China trade shock) produced substantial, concentrated, and persistent adjustment costs in developed-country labor markets because local labor-market frictions slow reallocation of workers and jobs

China experienced an exceptional manufacturing export surge since the 1990s that made it a dominant global manufacturer (share of world manufacturing exports rose from ~2% in 1991 to nearly 19% in 2013)
WTO accession, liberalization of exports, privatization, and access to imported inputs amplified China's export growth and productivity in manufacturing in the 1990s and 2000s

Empirical identification: studies instrument US industry import growth from China with contemporaneous Chinese export growth to other high-income countries and use gravity-based residuals to isolate supply-driven Chinese export expansion
At the industry level, greater import penetration from China causally reduces domestic manufacturing employment and increases plant exit and reallocation within industries

Local labor markets (US commuting zones) more exposed to Chinese import growth experienced larger declines in manufacturing employment, higher unemployment and nonparticipation, and only modest population migration even after a decade

Mechanisms amplifying effects: concentration of exposed industries in particular places, input-output upstream propagation to suppliers, and macro imbalances (China current account surpluses and US deficits) which can delay reallocation

Worker-level evidence: workers initially employed in industries heavily exposed to Chinese import growth accumulate lower lifetime earnings, experience more job churn, greater spells of disability receipt, and often move to other exposed firms or industries rather than into sheltered high-wage jobs

Wage margin and transfers: exposed local markets show greater declines in wages (especially lower quantiles of the wage distribution) and large increases in public transfer receipts (medical, retirement, disability, income assistance) while targeted trade assistance (TAA) provides negligible offset
Limited geographic mobility: empirical patterns show slow worker migration across regions and persistence of exposure even after job changes, implying large short- and medium-run local welfare losses

Conclusion: The China trade shock challenges prior consensus that trade effects are small and diffuse; instead trade can generate sizable distributional and adjustment costs concentrated among workers in exposed industries and localities
Policy implication: research and policy should focus on when and where trade is costly and on better tools to manage and mitigate localized, persistent adjustment costs

Assumption used in theoretical sketch: imperfect geographic labor mobility (extreme case of complete immobility) creates upward-sloping regional labor supply and justifies treating regional specialization as pre-determined in empirical exposure measures

Limitation and identification caveat: instrument validity requires that Chinese export patterns to other high-income countries capture supply-driven shocks rather than correlated global demand shocks; gravity and robustness checks mitigate but do not eliminate this concern
